newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS-Oil prices edge up but trend still sideways.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Oil prices edge up but trend still sideways.

text.p: World oil prices edged slightly higher on Monday but dealers said the underlying trend was broadly sideways.
Benchmark Brent crude oil futures for July delivery were up 15 cents at $19.54 a barrel at 1525 GMT.
The nearest Brent futures contract has averaged just $19 over the past three months after falling sharply from a high of $24.78 at the beginning of the year.
Although prices peaked at well over $20 last month many dealers have stayed sceptical of fledgling rallies in recent weeks.
"There's no urge to move out of the current price range," said Nigel Saperia, managing director of the oil division at Bankers Trust International in London.
"Fundamentally there's too much oil around but frankly there always is at this time of year," he added.
He said much still depended on the ability of U.S. gasoline demand to prop up the wider oil market this summer.
Western oil refiners may also lend support to the crude oil market in the coming weeks as healthy profit margins encourage higher throughputs.
A sharp drop in the value of physical Brent last week boosted margins by 45 cents a barrel for Rotterdam plants.

Tighter than expected supply of crude oil could also help prices. For the second year running analysts have cut their forecasts for non-OPEC supply growth because new North Sea fields have failed to come on stream when planned.

Market pundits reckon there will be a shortfall of 300,000 barrels per day, easing the downward price pressure on Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries oil, which has been under threat because of the cartel's own over-production.
Meanwhile, as expected the United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan recommended to the Security council that the six-month "oil for food" deal be renewed , a U.N. source said on Monday.
